documentation_interface_justification:
This is not a library, or API, or anything like that.
The user documentation describes what its input (how XMPP stanzas should be sent to it) and outputs are.
repo_public_justification:
https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi.git
https://git.louiz.org/biboumi
git://git.louiz.org/biboumi
repo_track_justification: https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/commits/master
repo_interim_justification: Everything is always public, all git revision are publicly available at all time.
repo_distributed_justification: Git is used.
version_unique_justification: Each stable release has x.y version number.
version_semver_justification:
The SemVer MINOR part is never used.
If a new feature is introduced, it’s a new major version. If only a bug fix is applied to a version, it’s a minor release.
Three numbers are too much and ugly.
version_tags_justification: Releases are tagged in git https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/tags
release_notes_vulns_justification: It identifies all the publicly known vulnerabilities: 0.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/issues/new?issue[confidential]=true

There’s a visible switch to make any issue confidential.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: It is, for all the 0 known vulnerabilities.
test_justification:
https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/tree/master/tests
Includes unit tests that work with any build configuration and no special configuration.
And an e2e tests that requires python3, slixmpp, and irc server etc, and which only works for the full config (project built with all dependencies).
test_most_justification: At least 80% are covered by the tests.
tests_are_added_justification:
https://codecov.io/gh/louiz/biboumi

It’s easy to see if the code coverage improved or not, with each commit.
know_common_errors_justification:
I know what a buffer overflow is.
And modern C++ is used to avoid these sort of bugs.
static_analysis_justification: libasan, coverity (https://scan.coverity.com/projects/louiz-biboumi), and valgrind are used.
static_analysis_often_justification: A coverity scan is submitted, and all tests are run on each git push.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/pipelines

All tests are run with many build configuration, on multiple OS.
discussion_justification:
https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/issues
https://lab.louiz.org/louiz/biboumi/merge_requests
xmpp:biboumi@muc.poez.io

an RPM for fedora is also provided.

name: yaml4rst
description: Linting/reformatting tool for YAML files documented with inline RST
interact_justification: The documentation show [how the software can be installed](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install.html). Feedback and contributing can be done in the usual way as documented by GitHub.

floss_license_osi_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
test_justification: There are multiple levels of testing involved. Refer to the [Makefile](https://github.com/ypid/yaml4rst/blob/master/Makefile) and the [Design prinipials](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/design.html).
test_invocation_justification: Either using `nosetests3` (unit testing); `make check` to run the full test suite or to run the full test suite before each commit run `make install-pre-commit-hook`.
test_most_justification: Full code coverage (including branch coverage) is enforced in the test suite. Refer to the [Design prinipials](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/design.html).
test_policy_justification: Full code coverage (including branch coverage) is enforced in the test suite. Refer to the [Design prinipials](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/design.html).
tests_are_added_justification: Full code coverage (including branch coverage) is enforced in the test suite. Refer to the [Design prinipials](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/design.html).
warnings_fixed_justification: Warnings are treated as errors, errors would make the CI test fail, commits with failed CI tests MUST NOT enter the project.
warnings_strict_justification: Warnings are treated as errors and are resolved.
delivery_mitm_justification: HTTPS + Authenticated software installation is the default as [documented](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install.html).
static_analysis_justification: Multiple static code analysis tools are being run on each commit. Refer to the [Makefile](https://github.com/ypid/yaml4rst/blob/master/Makefile) and the [Design prinipials](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/design.html).
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Pylint does a reasonable job here. If there are more checks available, they will be added and honored.
static_analysis_often_justification: The static code analysis tools are being run on each commit. Refer to the [Makefile](https://github.com/ypid/yaml4rst/blob/master/Makefile) and the [Design prinipials](https://yaml4rst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/design.html).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.

name: IPFS C++ API client library
description: A library that allows C++ applications to communicate with IPFS (https://ipfs.io). It implements IPFS API bindings (https://github.com/ipfs/interface-ipfs-core/tree/master/API) for C++.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api/master/LICENSE.MIT
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The "master" branch serves as interim review placeholder. Releases are created from it.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Each release is tagged from the "master" branch.
report_tracker_justification: GitHub issues track each individual bug report (issue).
report_responses_justification: The list of bug reports is at https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api/issues
enhancement_responses_justification: The list of enhancement requests is at https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api/issues (same as bug reports)
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api#contribute suggests that vulnerabilities are reported publicly.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities have been reported so far, so assuming this is met.
build_floss_tools_justification: The project requires cmake and C++ compiler. It depends on "JSON for Modern C++" and libcurl which are also buildable using only FLOSS tools.
test_justification: "make test" is provided - it runs various tests that exercise the methods provided by the library.
test_most_justification: The test suite covers 100% of the code. See the coverage badge(s) from https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api
test_policy_justification: https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api#contribute mentions code coverage should not go down.
tests_are_added_justification: The evidence is the git history. The test coverage is currently 100%.
tests_documented_added_justification: https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api#contribute mentions code coverage should not go down.
warnings_justification: The -Wall -Wpedantic -Wextra -Werror compiler warnings are used. In addition a static code analysis is performed using clang's scan-build tool as of 3b64e6e. Both methods find zero issues.
warnings_fixed_justification: No warnings area allowed in the first place since -Werror is used.
know_secure_design_justification: Vasil Dimov is the primary developer.
know_common_errors_justification: The provided library communicates with an IPFS server. The protocol that the library implements does not involve an authentication. As for the server itself - a malicious server could send bogus information as a response to the client, trying to exploit vulnerabilities in it.
crypto_published_justification: No custom cryptographic algorithms are devised by this project.
crypto_call_justification: No cryptography is used by the project itself.
crypto_floss_justification: No cryptography is used by the project itself.
crypto_keylength_justification: No cryptography is used by the project itself.
crypto_working_justification: No cryptography is used by the project itself.
crypto_pfs_justification: No cryptography is used by the project itself.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The software does not store passwords.
crypto_random_justification: No keys are generated by the software.
delivery_mitm_justification: Plaintext HTTP is used for communicating with the IPFS daemon, but it is supposed to run on the same machine (communication happens through the loopback interface). That is beyond the control of this project because the IPFS daemon does not provide a HTTPS access.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The library itself does not retrieve any cryptographic hashes.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No vulnerabilities have been reported so far.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No vulnerabilities have been reported so far.
static_analysis_justification: scan-build is run on every push. See https://travis-ci.org/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api
static_analysis_fixed_justification: No problems have been found so far.
static_analysis_often_justification: scan-build is run on every push. See https://travis-ci.org/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api
crypto_weaknesses_justification: No cryptography is used by the project itself.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Currently each push it tested by Travis CI, see the "build" badge on https://github.com/vasild/cpp-ipfs-api
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: This is the documentation in English: https://vasild.github.io/cpp-ipfs-api
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: darktable
description: darktable is an open source photography workflow application and raw developer
interact_justification: <https://www.darktable.org/install/> and  <https://www.darktable.org/development/> and the CONTRIBUTING.md in git
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: In <https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md> the coding style is described, there is also a clang-format file to automate part of that. The most important part, mentioned there and also on the website, is to talk with the team first to not waste time on something we won't accept later.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: <https://www.darktable.org/resources/> links to the usermanual (in a few languages) and several YouTube videos.
documentation_interface_justification: <https://www.darktable.org/usermanual/index.html.php> explains every detail of the user interface.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All work is done in the public git repository.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: We use SemVer with even/odd versions to indicate development versions (odd minor version)
version_tags_justification: We use git tags to mark releases
release_notes_justification: <https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/blob/master/RELEASE_NOTES> for drafting during the release cycle. The release notes of the final release is available on the mailing lists, GitHub's release page (where we also host the release tarballs) and our website (<https://www.darktable.org/news/>).
report_tracker_justification: We use redmine for bug tracking
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: https://www.darktable.org/contact/ mentions that vulnerabilities should be reported to the development mailing list.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There haven't been any such reports in the last 6 months.
build_floss_tools_justification: darktable can be built with CMake, make, gcc and some other free helper tools.
test_justification: There are some regression tests but none are publicly available so far. Mostly due to the private nature of the test data (photos provided by users).
test_policy_justification: As there is no automated test suit nothing can be added to it.
warnings_justification: We use "-Wall" and a few extra flags, see <https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/blob/master/cmake/compiler-warnings.cmake>
know_secure_design_justification: Being a regular desktop program most of the mentioned principles don't apply to darktable. Still we try hard to avoid any security problems by applying different tools to detect memory corruptions, buffer overflows and use after free bugs. We understand that this is an ongoing process and not a state that can be reached and then ignored in the future.
delivery_mitm_justification: All releases are signed with GPG. The fingerprint of the used key is put in some old release notes archived on several websites, it's on our website and also in our IRC channel's topic. For easo of use we also provide sha256 hashes of the released files.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The release page is available via HTTPS.
static_analysis_justification: We use clang's static analyzer as well as Coverity to check for bugs.
static_analysis_often_justification: This is work in progress, CI is supposed to run clang static analyzer eventually. We just have to figure out some details first.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We are using different -fsanitize builds for that. Parts of darktable are also tested with fuzzing tools.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: ASAN is routinely used to find bugs.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: A major part of darktable's code is speed critical, adding assertions to it is breaking the basic use case.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: <https://travis-ci.org/darktable-org/darktable> builds every commit and Pull Request.
discussion_justification: We use GitHub Pull Requests, our mailing lists are publicly archived and our bug tracker (<https://redmine.darktable.org/issues/>) is open, too.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: make install/uninstall works. We also have a PPA with Ubuntu packages and packages for OSX

name: Rosie Pattern Language (RPL) and the Rosie Pattern Engine
description:
Rosie is a supercharged alternative to Regular Expressions (regex), matching patterns against any input text. Rosie ships with hundreds of sample patterns for timestamps, network addresses, email addresses, CSV files, and many more.

Unlike most regex tools, Rosie can generate structured (JSON) output. And, Rosie has an interactive pattern development mode to help write and debug patterns.
